metadata.titleEn: Assessment data of tropical cyclone rainfall trends affecting China from 1951 to 2019
metadata.description: The original data source of the data sets: (1) released by the China national meteorological information center ground meteorological observation data basic V3.0 (on January 1, 1951 to December 31, 2019).(2) the Joint Typhoon warning Center (be Typhoon Warming Center) of typhoons in the northwestern Pacific best path data sets.Data processing method is: classifying and extracting Chinese basic ground meteorological observation data;  combing the daily rainfall data of 1951-2019 with 1951-2019 best path data of typhoons in the northwestern Pacific, using variation analysis model to classify and  calculate the tropical cyclone rainfall trend;summarying and ordering in accordance with the site number, form the table data.Data quality is good, relevant results have been published in SCI journals.Niu, Y., et al. "Assessing Heavy Precipitation Risk Associated with Tropical storms Cyclones in China." Journal of Applied Meteorology and Climatology. 5 (2022) : 61. Doi: 10.1175 / JAMC - D - 21-0166.1).
metadata.instructions: Influence of our country from 1951 to 2019 tropical cyclone rainfall trend assessment data

background: Tropical cyclone precipitation (TCP), accounting for some of the most extreme rainfall events, can lead to severe flooding and landslides, which often occur together as compound natural hazards during a tropical cyclone landfall. As one of the costliest and deadliest natural disasters, tropical cyclones (TCs) pose a high risk for global coastal regions. On average, nine tropical cyclones make landfall in China each year, bringing strong winds, storm surge, and heavy rainfall leading to severe property damages and loss of lives. Supertyphoon Haiyan, which made landfall in the Philippines, Vietnam, and Southeast China in November 2013, is one of the strongest tropical cyclones ever recorded in the region, causing 6000 fatalities and estimated damages of USD 4.55 billion (in 2013 values) resulting from a combination of rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind damages. From 1985 to 2002, an average of 483 deaths were caused by typhoons each year, and a total of 490,000 houses collapsed resulting in direct economic losses of CNY 34.7 billion (in 2000 values). These damages have been increasing in recent years over China; Chen et al. (2018) found a statistically significant increasing trend in the inflation-adjusted losses associated with tropical cyclones from 1983 to 2015. Tropical cyclone precipitation (TCP) plays an important role in TC-related damages. TCP can cause flooding and landslides and could lead to compounding impacts on coastal communities already affected by storm surge and strong winds.
research objective: In this study, we employ an advanced geostatistical framework to determine the TCP intensity and spatial extent along cyclone tracks for different cyclone categories, defined using the wind speed and tropical cyclone lifetime maximum intensity (LMI) at each track point ("point intensity-LMI"). Here we investigate the rainfall intensity and spatial extent by classifying and comparing the different types of tropical cyclones impacting China with varying intensities.
methods: Daily precipitation from the observational records of 699 meteorological stations in China, provided by the National Meteorological Information Center, China Meteorological Data Service Center, are used in this study. We also built two new binary datasets, Z1 and Z50, to identify stations that have exceeded precipitation thresholds of 1 and 50 mm for that day, respectively. The TC tracks are taken from the western North Pacific best-track dataset from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. We use the maximum sustained wind speed at each time step to classify the TC based on the TC descriptions from JTWC. We employ a moving neighborhood and semivariogram framework to analyze TCP spatial extent and intensity under the different point-LMI categories. We calculate the distribution of TCP for the 1951–2019 period in two ways. For the trend calculation at each station, we use the linear regression model function in R to calculate the regression coefficient, and we also use the Mann–Kendall trend test to check whether the trend is statistically significant.
dataset: Daily precipitation from the observational records of 699 meteorological stations in China, provided by the National Meteorological Information Center, China Meteorological Data Service Center, are used in this study. The station precipitation data were available from 1951 to 2019 at the time of the analysis, and the 699 stations are well distributed over Northeast China, East China, and South China. The TC tracks are taken from the western North Pacific best-track dataset from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. A total of 1788 TCs for the period 1951 to 2019.
findings: The results show that when a tropical cyclone with an LMI of a supertyphoon makes landfall and has weakened to tropical storm strength it usually produces the most intense rainfall and covers the largest spatial extent. The total TCP amount estimated using the varying spatial extent helps to determine more accurately the amount of seasonal rainfall that is from tropical cyclones in China. We also determined the rainfall trend from 1951 to 2019 for TCP and found that when compared with the inland stations the historical TCP rainfall trend in those stations near the coastline of China is significantly increasing. We found that the largest areas and heaviest intensities of rainfall occur when a supertyphoon has weakened to a tropical storm at landfall. When considering all tropical cyclones and their rainfall contribution to rainfall over land stations, we found that tropical cyclone rainfall has become heavier in most coastal areas of China.

Verification.Question: Does the data collection method involve using daily precipitation records from meteorological stations in China?
Are the precipitation data from 1951 to 2019 considered reliable for assessing trends in tropical cyclone precipitation in China?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the primary data collection method for assessing tropical cyclone precipitation trends based on observational records, remote sensing, or climate models?

Concept Completion.Question: What is the data collection method used to analyze tropical cyclone precipitation trends in China?
Concept Completion.Answer: Daily precipitation records from 699 meteorological stations in China

Concept Completion.Question: Where is the primary source of meteorological data for assessing tropical cyclone precipitation trends in China?
Concept Completion.Answer: National Meteorological Information Center, China Meteorological Data Service Center

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a method used to classify tropical cyclone precipitation intensity and spatial extent based on observational data?
Example.Answer: A method used involves employing a moving neighborhood and semivariogram framework to analyze tropical cyclone precipitation spatial extent and intensity under different point-LMI categories, using daily precipitation records from meteorological stations and TC tracks from a best-track dataset.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that could be used to assess rainfall trends associated with tropical cyclones in China?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset includes daily precipitation records from 699 meteorological stations across China, combined with TC track data from the western North Pacific best-track dataset spanning the period from 1951 to 2019.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection method used for assessing tropical cyclone precipitation trends?
Feature Specification.Answer: daily precipitation data, observational records, 699 meteorological stations in China, western North Pacific best-track dataset, Joint Typhoon Warning Center, moving neighborhood framework, semivariogram framework

Feature Specification.Question: What specific features are analyzed to determine the impact of tropical cyclones on precipitation patterns in China?
Feature Specification.Answer: intensity, spatial extent, cyclone categories, wind speed, lifetime maximum intensity, trend of precipitation intensity over time

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'semivariogram framework' in the context of tropical cyclone precipitation analysis?
Definition.Answer: In the context of tropical cyclone precipitation analysis, a 'semivariogram framework' is a geostatistical method used to analyze spatial patterns and relationships. It helps in understanding the spatial extent and intensity of rainfall by examining how rainfall variance changes with distance, which is crucial for assessing precipitation trends and impacts along cyclone tracks.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'point intensity-LMI' when classifying tropical cyclones?
Definition.Answer: 'Point intensity-LMI' refers to the classification of tropical cyclones based on the wind speed and the tropical cyclone's lifetime maximum intensity (LMI) at each track point. This classification helps in investigating the rainfall intensity and spatial extent for different cyclone categories, contributing to a more nuanced understanding of their impact on rainfall distribution.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of geostatistical frameworks in assessing tropical cyclone precipitation trends compare to traditional statistical methods?
Comparison.Answer: The use of geostatistical frameworks, such as semivariogram models, allows for a more detailed spatial analysis of tropical cyclone precipitation trends, capturing both intensity and spatial extent variations along cyclone tracks. Traditional statistical methods, like linear regression, mainly focus on trend analysis at individual stations, offering insights into temporal changes without detailed spatial interactions. Geostatistical methods provide a more nuanced understanding of precipitation distribution, especially in complex terrain and varied cyclone categories.

Interpretation.Question: What factors could contribute to variations in tropical cyclone precipitation data collected from meteorological stations across different regions in China?
Interpretation.Answer: Variations in tropical cyclone precipitation data across different regions in China could be influenced by geographical factors such as proximity to the coast, elevation differences, and regional climate variations. Additionally, the intensity and path of tropical cyclones, as well as the spatial distribution of meteorological stations, can affect data patterns.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of geostatistical frameworks improve the understanding of precipitation trends associated with tropical cyclones over a long-term dataset?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of geostatistical frameworks can enhance the understanding of precipitation trends by providing a more detailed spatial analysis of cyclone tracks and rainfall patterns. This method allows for the classification and comparison of different cyclone intensities and their impact on precipitation distribution, contributing to a more precise assessment of long-term trends.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the combination of observational records and best-track datasets be utilized to refine data collection methods for assessing tropical cyclone impacts?
Interpretation.Answer: Combining observational records with best-track datasets allows for a comprehensive analysis of tropical cyclone impacts by correlating precipitation data with cyclone intensity and paths. This approach can refine data collection methods by improving the classification of cyclone events and identifying significant trends in precipitation patterns related to tropical cyclones.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the effective integration of multiple data sources in assessing tropical cyclone precipitation trends in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The effective integration is achieved by combining daily precipitation data from 699 meteorological stations in China with the western North Pacific best-track dataset from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The integration allows for a comprehensive analysis of tropical cyclone precipitation (TCP) trends by employing a geostatistical framework and semivariogram models to analyze TCP intensity and spatial extent along cyclone tracks.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the use of a semivariogram framework essential in determining the spatial extent and intensity of tropical cyclone precipitation?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The semivariogram framework is essential as it allows for the analysis of TCP spatial extent and intensity under different point-LMI categories by providing a moving neighborhood approach. This method helps in accurately determining the rainfall distribution along cyclone tracks, which is critical for understanding the varying impacts of different intensities of tropical cyclones.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes behind the observed increasing trend in tropical cyclone precipitation near the coastline of China from 1951 to 2019?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The observed increasing trend in tropical cyclone precipitation near the coastline of China is attributed to the historical TCP rainfall trend analysis using linear regression models and Mann–Kendall trend tests. These analyses show that when a supertyphoon weakens to a tropical storm at landfall, it produces the most intense rainfall and covers the largest spatial extent, contributing to heavier rainfall in most coastal areas.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using a linear regression model and Mann–Kendall trend test in analyzing rainfall trends over an extended period?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a linear regression model and Mann–Kendall trend test in analyzing rainfall trends provides a robust statistical approach to determine the significance and direction of trends over a long period. This approach helps in validating whether the observed changes in rainfall, such as the increasing trend of TCP near coastal stations, are statistically significant, thereby enhancing the reliability of long-term climatic assessments.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is employing a geostatistical framework essential in analyzing tropical cyclone precipitation intensity and spatial extent?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Employing a geostatistical framework is essential for accurately determining the intensity and spatial extent of TCP along cyclone tracks. This method allows for the classification and comparison of different tropical cyclone types impacting China, facilitating a better understanding of how varying intensities affect rainfall distribution and associated risks.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of using a moving neighborhood and semivariogram framework in tropical cyclone precipitation research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes include detailed analyses of TCP spatial extent and intensity under different cyclone categories, providing insights into how tropical cyclones contribute to seasonal rainfall. This approach helps in identifying significant trends in TCP and assessing the increasing trend of TCP-related rainfall in coastal areas of China.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to integrate different data sources to assess tropical cyclone precipitation trends over an extended period?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The integration involves combining daily precipitation data from 699 meteorological stations in China with tropical cyclone track data from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The process includes the classification and extraction of relevant rainfall data, followed by using a semivariogram framework to analyze the spatial extent and intensity of tropical cyclone precipitation over the period from 1951 to 2019.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the trend analysis for tropical cyclone precipitation conducted to ensure statistical significance?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Trend analysis is conducted using a linear regression model function in R to compute the regression coefficient for each station. The Mann–Kendall trend test is also employed to verify the statistical significance of the trends identified in the tropical cyclone precipitation data from 1951 to 2019.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to categorize and compare different types of tropical cyclones affecting China based on their intensity?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Tropical cyclones are categorized using the wind speed and tropical cyclone lifetime maximum intensity (LMI) at each track point. This classification employs a moving neighborhood and semivariogram framework to analyze the intensity and spatial extent of the rainfall associated with each category, aiding in the comparison of different tropical cyclone impacts on China.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the integration of meteorological data from multiple sources to assess trends in tropical cyclone precipitation in China?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of meteorological data from multiple sources is enabled by combining daily precipitation records from 699 meteorological stations with the best-track dataset of the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. These datasets are used within a geostatistical framework, employing methods such as a moving neighborhood and semivariogram analysis to evaluate precipitation trends and intensities for tropical cyclones from 1951 to 2019.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of advanced statistical models enable the classification and trend analysis of tropical cyclone precipitation?
Enablement.Answer: The use of advanced statistical models, such as the linear regression model and the Mann–Kendall trend test, enables the classification and trend analysis of tropical cyclone precipitation by calculating regression coefficients and determining statistical significance for rainfall trends at each meteorological station over the period from 1951 to 2019.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset on tropical cyclone precipitation trends in China from 1951 to 2019 be expected to exhibit regional variations, especially near coastal areas?
Expectation.Answer: The findings indicate that historical tropical cyclone precipitation (TCP) rainfall trends near the coastline of China are significantly increasing compared to inland stations. This suggests regional variations, potentially due to the interaction of cyclones with the coastal geography, leading to differences in rainfall intensity and spatial extent.

Expectation.Question: Why would a research approach focusing on the rainfall intensity and spatial extent of tropical cyclones benefit from employing a moving neighborhood and semivariogram framework?
Expectation.Answer: The methods described employ a moving neighborhood and semivariogram framework to analyze TCP spatial extent and intensity under different point-LMI categories. This approach likely benefits from capturing the localized and variable nature of rainfall distribution associated with tropical cyclones, allowing for a detailed and nuanced assessment of rainfall intensity and its spatial extent.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the methods used to determine the intensity and spatial extent of tropical cyclone precipitation using geostatistical frameworks.
Assertion.Answer: The study uses a moving neighborhood and semivariogram framework to analyze the spatial extent and intensity of tropical cyclone precipitation. This involves classifying tropical cyclones based on wind speed and lifetime maximum intensity, then investigating rainfall intensity and spatial extent along cyclone tracks.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a data collection method used for obtaining daily precipitation records in the context of tropical cyclone impact assessments.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection method involves using daily precipitation records from 699 meteorological stations in China, provided by the National Meteorological Information Center, China Meteorological Data Service Center. These records cover the period from 1951 to 2019, and the stations are well distributed across Northeast China, East China, and South China.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential methods for expanding existing datasets to improve the accuracy of tropical cyclone rainfall trend analysis in China.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential methods for expanding existing datasets could include incorporating additional meteorological stations to increase spatial coverage, utilizing satellite-based precipitation estimates for areas lacking ground-based stations, and integrating historical climate data to enhance the temporal range of the analysis. Employing advanced statistical models or machine learning techniques to refine the spatial and temporal resolution of the datasets could also improve accuracy.
